thread.title: China punishes illegal share sales
thread.title_full: China punishes illegal share sales | Business Spectator

author: Dow Jones newswires
title: China punishes illegal share sales
text:
China's stock regulator imposed a total penalty of 28.4 million yuan ($US4.6 million) Tuesday for eight cases of illegal selloff of shares, underscoring the authority's tightening rules to restrict downward pressure on the market.
The selloff case involving the most money came to 18.3 million yuan while the case with the highest rate of share sales was 3.83 per cent, the China Securities Regulatory Commission said in its announcement of the penalties on its website late on Tuesday.
One of the commission's measures to halt the market plunge over the summer was a six-month ban on shareholders who own more than 5 per cent of a given company selling their shares, starting July 8.
In a separate statement on Tuesday, the commission disclosed details of 11 additional investigations it had completed, including allegations of insider trading, manipulation of index futures and spreading false information.
On September 18, the commission punished nearly 20 companies for alleged "illegal market activities" and imposed roughly 1.1 billion yuan worth of penalties.
The commission has pursued a sustained campaign to minimize market irregularities since the beginning of the stock market turmoil in July, which has wiped out nearly $US5 trillion in shareholder value. The securities watchdog has penalised brokerage firms for allowing unregulated margin lending to run rampant. It has also issued a spate of warnings to retail and institutional investors for illegal trading such as stock price manipulation.
The Shanghai Stock Exchange fell 2 per cent to 3038.14 yesterday, down 41 per cent from its peak in mid-June.
